title: Simple circuits - why are bulbs 1 and 2 lit or not

content.question: The figure shows a circuit that includes a battery, two lightbulbs, and two switches. Switch <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is open and Switch <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is closed. Are the two bulbs lit or unlit, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: The bulbs are lit. Bulbs <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are in a closed loop with each other and are connected to the battery terminal on the left.

The bulbs are lit. Electrons can move from the left terminal of the battery, rightward through Bulb <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, and then leftward through Bulb <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> before returning to the battery.

The bulbs are unlit. The wrong side of the battery is connected to the closed loop containing bulbs <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
The bulbs are unlit. The battery is not connected in a closed loop with either of the bulbs.

content.answer: The bulbs are unlit. The battery is not connected in a closed loop with either of the bulbs.
